updates.update_content:
Dear fans of animation,
The Kickstarter campaign for Laika is at its end. We’d like to thank each and every one of you enormously for helping us get closer to our goal. One that – sadly – we have not fully reached.
With neither the time nor resources for a wide-ranging PR effort or social media campaigns, we decided to try and answer a simple question – will the lively Kickstarter community be enough on its own to help finish a relatively niche yet beautiful independent work?

updates.update_userinfo: The mover and shaker – Olivie Dolanská
updates.update_content:
Today, we’d like you to meet Olivie, one of the animators working on Laika, or in her own words – “one of the weird people you don’t normally even see.” But that doesn’t mean she’s not important. Quite the opposite, in fact.
As you may already be used to hearing in these updates, her job isn’t exactly a cake walk – hardly anything is when it comes to animation. In this video, she explains quite a bit about her role and its sometimes less obvious pitfalls. See for yourself, you might be surprised to hear what an animator has to undergo in order to make a living around here.

updates.update_userinfo: Anatomy of a puppet with Ondřej Zíka
updates.update_content:
The history of Czech puppetry is long and colourful, spanning all the way from Jiří Trnka through the works of Břetislav Pojar and these days, Aurel Klimt.
But there’s been one constant over the last few decades and that is the indisputable master behind the construction of these puppets – Ondřej Zíka. He has been producing the most sophisticated and ingenious skeletons, thanks to which many filmmakers including Jiří Trnka, Jan Švankmajer or Aurel Klimt could realise their visions.

updates.update_userinfo: Introducing Martin Velíšek, one of the art directors of Laika
updates.update_content:
Today, we’d like you to meet Martin Velíšek. He’s not just a man responsible for the art direction of Laika and other of Klimt's films, he's a remarkable artist in his own right.
Martin is a one-of-a-kind enfant terrible of the Czech artistic world. He originally studied in the glass-working department College of Industrial Art in Prague and the fact that he graduated as one of Stanislav Libenský’s students was in itself viewed as an indisputable mark of quality. His style is not easy to define, but the dominant theme in Velíšek’s work is man, or better put, the body of man, generally closed in a space in his nakedness or before a horizon. He never shies away from the bizzare, the grotesque and the surreal and that’s why he found his perfect match in the form of his friend, Aurel Klimt.

comments.content: Please don't give up. This looked like it was shaping up to be an amazing, award winning film. Please keep me posted on your progress and future plans. I would really like to see this get made.
May your art take you to new heights, and the whole production be a smashing success!

So sorry your campaign missed the target amount. I think this will be an awesome film -- you are obviously quite talented! I'd certainly be interested in any future opportunities to help support your work. Please keep me posted!

Maybe you could break the postproduction into smaller chunks, with new, less ambitious, crowdsourcing campaigns, to work around the "all or nothing" policy... If you do, I'm sure a lot of your backers would join you again. Count me in!

campaign.story:
Judy Grahn: Hanging On Our Own Bones
I am the wall at the lip of the water
I am the rock that refused to be battered
I am the dyke in the matter, the other
I am the wall with the womanly swagger
I am the dragon, the dangerous dagger
I am the bulldyke, the bulldagger
and I have been many a wicked grandmother
and I shall be many a wicked daughter.  
—Judy Grahn
Join Red Hen Press in publishing Judy Grahn’s Hanging On Our Own Bones, the newest collection of poetry by one of the most acclaimed LGBTQ and feminist writers of the last half century. With your help, we will reintroduce a defining voice in queer and women’s movements to a new generation of activists and readers.
Official cover image for Hanging On Our Own Bones
Hanging On Our Own Bones collects over forty years of Judy Grahn’s signature nine-part poems, including “A Woman is talking to Death,” often referred to as one of the most important poems of the twentieth century. These poems address issues crucial to our contemporary and often difficult world. Here Grahn’s steadfast and rhythmic verse directs our eyes to crucial yet often buried tribulations of our times by critiquing white supremacy, honoring battered women, exalting the powers of menstruation, and revealing lateral hostilities among potential allies—all to arouse a meaningful social critique.  
As a backer, you will receive not only a copy of this incredible book, but also the knowledge that your support is introducing today’s activists to the champion they never knew they had—a fighter whose work has paved the way for all who followed.
Who is Judy Grahn?   
 “Anyone who reads Grahn will be changed for life. Repeat: for life.” 
—Alicia Ostriker
Judy Grahn, copyright 1988 by Robert Giard
Poet, writer, and cultural theorist, Judy Grahn has been at the forefront of gay and lesbian activism and women’s spirituality movements since the 1960s. Grahn’s works have been a rallying cry for women’s movements since before she was ever published, going viral before the Internet even existed.   
Judy Grahn set out to be a poet at the age of nine, studying the poetic forms while asking the crucial question, What is poetry for? How does a poem connect with people and add meaning or strength to lives? Along the way she developed a distinct perspective—a fierce song—that is evident in the countless collections, poetic plays, dance dramas, and collaborations with musicians and songwriters she has produced.  
In 1999, Judy Grahn’s book Another Mother Tongue served as the major theme of the Seattle Gay Pride Parade. In 1996, the Publishing Triangle, an association of lesbians and gay men in publishing, established an award in her name: The Judy Grahn Award, recognizing the best nonfiction book of the year. In June 2017, she will receive the Fred Cody Award for Lifetime Achievement in Literature and Community Service.
Grahn’s work has won numerous other awards and honors, including an American Book Review Award, two American Book Awards, a Stonewall (American Library) Award, the Bill Whitehead Lifetime Achievement in Lesbian Letters Award, and two Lambda book awards. She is currently an Associated Distinguished Professor in Integral and Transpersonal Psychology at the California Institute of Integral Studies in San Francisco, where in the 1990s she earned her PhD in Integral Studies. She served as co-director for an MA program in Women’s Spirituality for thirteen years, and for an MFA in Creative Inquiry for five years.
Advance Praise for Hanging On Our Own Bones
“Skin, jail, butterfly, hospital, street, mother, father, blood, war: such words come alive as survivor, witness, and guide. Judy Grahn uses the tried and true heart of the ballad to explore the socially unsaid and unsayable. Animated by the heroism and mythology of the everyday, and armed with attention and wisdom, she is a fierce warrior for the clarity of the human story.”
—Ammiel Alcalay, author of neither wit nor gold
“All the poets I know look upon Judy Grahn with admiration and awe, convinced that she’s leagues ahead of us, superhuman in her power and insight. But the poet of these chants of grief and frustration—and hope—is human for sure, torn by the same powerlessness and disgust at prevalent social conditions as the rest of us—it’s only that she has lightning at her command—a magic of writing that illuminates shreds darkness like confetti, and lets us see past the end of each page, past all our histories, a magic that lets us glimpse a previously unimagined future.”
—Kevin Killian, author of Impossible Princess  
About Arktoi Books  
Named after the girls impersonating she-bears in service of the goddess Artemis, Arktoi Books is an imprint of Red Hen Press publishing high-quality literary fiction and poetry by lesbian writers. It was established in 2006 to give lesbian writers more access to “the conversation” that having a book in print affords. Eloise Klein Healy, Arktoi’s founder and editor, is the 2016 recipient of the Publishing Triangle’s Bill Whitehead Award for Lifetime Achievement.  
Following the release of Hanging On Our Own Bones, Arktoi will go into hibernation indefinitely. It’s especially fitting that Judy Grahn’s collection of lamentations in nine parts wraps up the series, as it will be the imprint’s ninth book. While not a direct replacement, Red Hen’s new award series for queer writers, Quill, edited by Tobi Harper, will help carry the torch. The first book in the series, Scissors, Paper, Stone by lesbian writer Martha K. Davis, will be released in spring 2018. We aren’t ruling out the possibility that Arktoi could return down the road, but for the foreseeable future, it will no longer acquire any new titles. All Arktoi books will remain in print and the imprint will otherwise remain active.
About the Publisher 
Red Hen Press has served both local and national communities as Southern California’s largest nonprofit literary publisher for 23 years. Our mission is to discover and publish works of literary excellence, support diversity, and promote literacy in our local schools. Dr. Kate Gale and Mark E. Cull co-founded the press in 1994 from their San Fernando Valley home when they sold nearly all they owned to begin publishing talented writers whose works had been overlooked by large-scale publishers. Over the past 23 years, Red Hen Press has published over 400 books and transformed into a thriving organization that supports the Greater Los Angeles Area and international communities with arts-based events and literary advocacy.
Red Hen is proud to have partnered with Judy Grahn again and again throughout her illustrious career. Her book love belongs to those who do the feeling was published by Red Hen Press in 2008. Most recently, Grahn was a featured reader at a joint Red Hen Press and Women’s Center of Los Angeles event in celebration of feminist poets spanning a generation. It is an honor to have the opportunity to work with Judy Grahn on her fourteenth book, and a greater honor still to consider her a friend of Red Hen.
About love belongs to those who do the feeling 
love belongs to those who do the feeling contains selections from Judy’s entire body of poetic work, from classics such as “The Work of a Common Woman” and “The Queen of Wands and The Queen of Swords,” to new poems written between 1997 and 2006. The collection was the 2009 winner of the Lambda Literary Award for Lesbian Poetry.
Official cover image for the special edition reprint of love belongs to those who do the feeling
“[Judy Grahn] is a phenomenon—a fierce poet of witness and action, a visionary, with a tough and compassionate heart and a piercing intelligence, rooted in a spirituality that locates the sacred in the belly of the profane.”
 —Alicia Ostriker, winner of the Jewish National Book Award
The 2017 special edition reprint of love belongs to those who do the feeling will be bound and designed to be distributed as a set with Hanging On Our Own Bones.
About the Benefit and Cocktail Party
Red Hen Press’s annual Benefit, held each year in November in Pasadena, features an afternoon Champagne Luncheon with festivities highlighting Red Hen’s vibrant tradition in the literary community, including performances from local school children, a silent auction, and readings by acclaimed authors.  
This year’s Benefit will take place on November 12, 2017, and will feature esteemed writers and poets Camille Dungy, winner of the American Book Award for Suck on the Marrow; Viet Thanh Nguyen, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of The Sympathizer; and A. E. Stallings, 2011 Macarthur Fellow and author of Archaic Smile. 
In addition to the Sunday Benefit Champagne Luncheon, Red Hen holds an exclusive Cocktail Party the evening preceding the Benefit, featuring an additional private, short reading from the Benefit's featured readers, catered food and drinks, and plenty of mingling time. This invite-only event offers guests a chance to interact with the readers in an intimate and relaxed setting, as well as meet many of Red Hen’s authors and staff.
Proceeds raised through the Benefit Luncheon and Cocktail Party help Red Hen Press continue its tradition of literary excellence by supporting its publications, community reading series, and programs, including the press’s work in local schools.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Red Hen Press’s commitment to literary excellence, unique status as a Southern California–based press with national reach, and long partnership and friendship with Judy Grahn are what make Hanging On Our Own Bones a project that is close to our hearts.

We see no obstacles to the successful execution of this project, but as a nonprofit press, our greatest challenge is acquiring funding to produce books like Hanging On Our Own Bones that don’t just entertain—they edify. Our mission is to provide you with literature that seeks to answer life’s most evasive questions, but we can’t do it without your help. Join us in bringing this astounding collection to life!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: New Campaign; New Judy Grahn's book; New Quill Judge!
updates.update_content:
Dear Friends,
We hope you and yours are doing well.
In case you have not heard, on June 1st we launched another Kickstarter Campaign to promote a young, up-and-coming queer author, Chelsea Catherine, and her prize-winning book, SUMMER OF THE CICADAS, in celebration of Pride Month.
Given the state of events as they unfolded this month, we realized the ill-timing of our project when it was too late. For the first week, we made the decision to shift our promotional efforts to focus on amplifying Black Lives Matter and the voices of our Black allies. However, as this project nears its end, we owe it to our LGBTQ+ community and upcoming Quill authors to see this campaign through.

We made it!
With your enthusiasm and generosity, we surpassed our original funding goal by over $1,000.
In the next few weeks, we'll be sending out contribution letters for your tax records as well as backer surveys to make sure you your rewards, so keep an eye out!

Congratulations to poet, activist, and cultural theorist Judy Grahn who this week was presented with the Fred Cody Award for lifetime achievement and literary service!

With just one week left till the end of this kickstarter project, we are right on track to raise the funds to help print Hanging On Our Own Bones and the redesigned love belongs to those who do the feeling. Thank you for your support, and please spread the word about this opportunity to get signed pre-sale copies!

" collects over forty years of what Judy Grahn calls her 'ninepart poems,' and here clearly identifies them as 'lamentations.' All the poets I know look upon Judy Grahn with admiration and awe, convinced that she's leagues ahead of us, superhuman in her power and insight. But the poet of these chants of grief and frustration--and hope--is human for sure, torn by the same powerlessness and disgust at prevalent social conditions as the rest of us--it's only that she has lightning at her command--a magic of writing that illuminates, shreds darkness like confetti, and lets us see past the end of each page, past all our histories, a magic that lets us glimpse a previously unimagined future." --Kevin Killian

Judy Grahn came to fame in the 1960s as a feminist poet and an activist--she picketed the White House in 1965 for Gay rights--and became an iconic figure fueling second wave feminism, gay and lesbian activism, and women's spirituality movements. Author of six collectiosn of poetry, from (1971) to (2008), with a seventh forthcoming in August 2017, , an ecotopian novel, short stories, articles, and four nonfiction books, including , and . She has recently published both and the memoir She co-founded Gay Women's Liberation and the Women's Press Collective in 1969, and currently serves as Research Faculty for the Institute of Transpersonal Psychology in Palo Alto, California. She is former director of Women's Spirituality MA and Creative Inquiry MFA programs at New College of California. She is a performer; her work has been put to music by jazz groups, rock groups, chorale groups; her book-length poems and have been choreographed and staged, and two CDs have been released of her collaborations with singer-songwriter Ann Carol Mitchell. Judy Grahn is truly a fountain of eloquence, courage, and radiant wisdom for our times.

campaign.story:
We need your support! 
We have been partially funded by Burning Man Honorarium to start this project, but we need your help to bring this pyramid to its full potential. We are raising funds to cover basic materials & fabrication costs.
Current designs have this as a 4 tiered pyramid: 
Our budget only allowed us to fill the top 3 tiers with gummy bears, with the bottom tier being empty.
The additional funds we raise will go to: casting materials, metal, acrylic sheets, hardware, and lighting. 
With your help, we can bring this Pyramid to fruition by filling the bottom tier with bears too to make this a fully encased glowing installation. 
Breakdown of costs: 
Material Costs add up really fast working on something this large scale and we still have a lot of work to do to bring this project to life. Total predicted breakdown of costs exceeds $20,000! We are starting with an initial goal of raising $10,000 (which helps to cover basic material costs) and stretching for $20,000 to build that bottom tier. If we reach our initial goal, then we have some exciting stretch goal (new rewards) in store for you!
200,000 hand casted gummy bears: $5500 
Metal & Hardware: $4800 
Acrylic frames: $3900 
Light, Electrical, & Power: $2900 
Specialty Services Fabrication: $1200 
Studio Build Rental: $3000 
Transportation: $1200 
Reward Creation: $1500+ 
Fees: $1000+
    Why Gummy Bears?
The original idea came about in 2012 when the lead artist, Dicapria, began to experiment with ideas for a new light installation series. The artist, who has been inspired for years by various architectural line work, tibetan buddhist sand mandalas, stained glass, crop circles, and lite-brite turned to this unlikely medium for her then 2013 Art Series: Gummy Bear Mandalas in light boxes. By collaborating with an amazing crew, we are able to extend that art series to a more all-encompassing, experiential, geometric (3d) structure of the pyramid shape.
Will they melt?
We are working very hard with SCIENCE and MAGIC to make sure that doesn't happen.
Can I lick the pyramid?
If you'd like..the bears might be dusty, but sure! 
Exactly how many bears will it take?
You tell us! We are offering a special prize to the nearest guess. (Share this kickstarter campaign on facebook, tag us at Gummy Bear Pyramid, and include your guess so we can keep track.
Be a part of bringing this Gummy Bear Pyramid to life! 
We offer many exciting rewards as a thank you for supporting our project.
You can also make a tax deductible donation through our fiscal sponsorship page and be issued a tax receipt. https://connect.clickandpledge.com/Organization/burningmanproject/campaign/gummybearpyramid
   NEW REWARDS ADDED!!
         If you cannot donate at this time, but still wish to help us reach our goal, please help us spread the word. Share this crowdfunding page with your friends on social media or through email. This really does help a lot! And we are super grateful!
Want to Volunteer? Come build with us at American Steel Studios in Oakland, California. Tell us your interest level and skill sets. We are looking for metal workers, mold making/casting people, and all around crafty people that want to join in on our fun crew build nights. gummybearpyramid@gmail.com
Open Play in the Pyramid. We want to encourage people to play inside the pyramid. This is a pyramid dedicated to awaken the IMAGINATION. We want to give YOU the chance to share your creativity with others, whether it be the dream you had last night, your thoughts on existential dimensions, quantum physics, live music, performance art, dance, or even a game. All are welcome to play and share their minds with others inside the Gummy Bear Pyramid.
Follow our journey here! 
www.dicapria.com/pyramid 
www.instagram.com/dicapriaart   @dicapriaart
www.facebook.com/gummybearpyramid
fiscal sponsorship (make a tax deductible donation and receive a tax receipt) 
gummybearpyramid@gmail.com
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We are excited to be building this project and it is already underway of being built. Some design decisions might have to be altered slightly depending on the funds we raise here to fit within the budget. 

Rewards: We are hoping to finish some rewards pre-playa, but since we are mainly focused on building this main installation, we have planned to provide rewards by November 2017 to give us a little breathing room. Since many of the rewards are hand built by us, too many orders could cause a back-log. This may cause a short delay and would be communicated if that is the case. 
If you have any suggestions or comments or want to help, feel free to reach out to us. 

And once again, Thank you for your support! We are grateful to be building our passion project and couldn't do this without you!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Computational Textiles: Endless Horizon
Computational Textiles is a project by Phillip David Stearns, Artist and Designer, Founder of GlitchTextiles.com launched on Kickstarter in 2012.
This project extends the work of GlitchTextiles, starting with glitches and expanding outwards to explore the full horizon of working with textiles as a computational medium. We're offering reboots of older 2012 designs as well as all new rewards made with new Computational Textile fabrics.
Computational Textiles are a form of materializing and reconnecting with the history and possibility of our digital past, present and future. As a medium, they enable us to physically and visually experience our digital materiality. Through structure and from, my desire is to bring to common places, the uncommon beauty of the invisible side of our digital world.
Computational Textiles Fabric Examples
Our new fabrics are high quality material realizations of digital processes and material. We work with weavers in North Carolina and the Netherlands, harnessing the rich tradition and craftsmanship from two of the most historically important textile producing regions on either side of the Atlantic in the 20th century.
Here are some examples of the fabrics we've created for this project:
Computational Textiles
Clouds of Icarus (Row 1): A medium weight double weave fabric made from 100% organic cotton. Designed using node based texture programming in Blender.
Gravitational Lens (Row 2 Left): A medium weight double weave fabric made from 100% organic cotton. Designed using node based texture programming in Blender.
Special Op (Row 2 Right): A medium to light weight single weave fabric made from 100% organic cotton. Designed using node based texture programming in Blender.
Endless Horizon (Row 3): Granular (Left) and Smooth (Right) variations are medium weight double weave fabrics made from 100% organic cotton or acrylic. Designed using custom software written with Processing.
Binary Noise (Row 4): Single (Left) and Double (Right) Weave Constructions. Available in a range of colors. Single weave fabrics are tone on white. Double weave fabrics are two-color. Compositions available in cotton and merino wool blend.
Living Code (Row 5): A medium to light weight single weave fabric made from 100% organic cotton. Designed using custom software written with Processing based on an extended version of Wolfram's 1D Cellular Automata.
GlitchTextiles Gold Edition Designs
GlitchTextiles Gold Edition Designs
From left to right, top to bottom: PIC00008, DCP_0053, DCP02802, DCP02803, YOTG-192, YOTG-198, DCP_2994, DCP_2995
These 8 designs are select favorites from the 2012 GlitchTextiles campaign. Throws, Scarves, Totes, and Zipper Pouches will be offered in a selection of these designs. Totes and Zipper pouches have minimums so can't be offered in all 8 designs and although a finer tapestry material will be used, not all of the design will be visible on the Totes and Zipper pouches.
Here are some rad things we've made with the fabric so far!
Zipper Pouches (10"x5"):
$30 Gold Edition - Features designs from the 2012 GlitchTextiles Kickstarter Campaign. Made in the US.
$40 Computational Textiles - Features all new Computational Textiles fabric. Woven in the Netherlands, cut and sewn in Brooklyn.
 Laptop Sleeves  - $50 for 13" and $75 for 15" laptops - Woven in the Netherlands, cut and sewn in Brooklyn.
15" Laptop Sleeve in Clouds of Icarus fabric
Gold Edition Woven Scarf - $60 - 12"x71" Jacquard Woven Scarf - made in the US.
100% Cotton Jacquard Woven Scarf (Example of Material and Quality)
Gold Edition Scarf Designs
Woven Merino Scarf - $100 - woven in the Netherlands, finished in Brooklyn.
80/20 Merino/Cotton Blend, Featuring Binary Noise Design
 Gold Edition Woven Throws - $250 - 53"x71" Jacquard Woven Blankets - Made in the US.
100% Cotton Jacquard Woven Gold Edition Throws
 Gold Edition Throw Pillows - $120 - 20"x20" - made in the US.
Gold Edition Throw Pillows
Computational Textiles Throw Pillows - $150 - 20"x20" - Woven in the Netherlands, cut and sewn in the Brooklyn.
Computational Textiles Pillow in Gravitational Lens Fabric
Computational Textiles Throw Blanket - $500 - 60"x80" Luxuriously soft merino wool blanket featuring the Living Code design motifs. Made in the Netherlands.
Merino Wool Throw featuring the Wolfram's Web Design
Custom Theories of Everything Artwork - $1250 - 18" x 24" Original Textile Artwork made from cut, sewn, and stretched Computational Textile Fabric.
Theories of Everything 007
I've been working with Pure Country Weavers and the TextielLab to develop these new designs and fabrics. These materials are all computationally designed and woven on computer controlled looms. They are computational textiles.
Funds from this campaign will support continued development of eye popping designs, the establishment of US based manufacturing, the production of stock for distribution in textile showrooms, testing for materials certification, and continued development in the US and NL.
Past Work: Glitch Textiles (5 Years and counting)
Glitch Textiles for Dior Cruise 2015 Collection
In 2012 GlitchTextiles launched on Kickstarter marking the beginning of an amazing and rewarding journey in textile design. Some highlights include:
TextielLab residency in 2013 to produce the Fragmented Memory digital tapestry pieces featured in numerous publications.
A feature in the “Glitch @ Tokyo Kaihouku” pop-up shop in the famous Isetan Shinjuku department store (2014)
The once in a lifetime opportunity to design and produce fabric for Christian Dior’s 2015 Cruise Collection (2014)
A feature in the “Brooklyn” pop-up shop in the world renowned Le Bon Marché department store (2015)
Contributing a design to the talented, up and coming men’s fashion label DDUGOFF (2014)Inclusion in the New Museum Store collection (2013)
Inclusion in the New Museum Store collection (2013)
Everything that GlitchTextiles has become in the past 5 years is thanks to the support from Kickstarter backers, bloggers, writers and media, the fine folks of Pure Country Weavers, the TextielLab, PhotoThrow.com, loyal customers and fans, and all my family and friends who have been supportive, encouraging and have helped spread the word.
Thank you for backing the project. Please help spread the word by sharing on your favorite social media platforms!

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
All rewards have gone through development to production prototype. The only work remaining is to produce and deliver to you.

The risks are minimal, but still present. With two major campaigns under our belt, we're ready to handle any challenges that might arise:

Yarn selection may become unavailable. This might simply slow down fulfillment, or it might impact the available composition or color choices. If this occurs, you'll be notified and presented with alternatives.

Production delays. If for some reason production and fulfillment delays will cause your reward to arrive beyond the estimated arrival date, we'll let you know and provide as much info as we can about the cause and what's being done, and when things will get moving again. Thanks for your patience and understanding!

Shipping delays. We work with trusted shipping services, but even the best sometimes experience delays. All international orders are fulfilled with USPS International Priority which usually delivers between 5-8 business days. Domestic US shipping is done via FedEx and usually takes between 3-5 business days. We'll send tracking information with all shipments.

Rewards lost or damaged in the mail. All shipments will be covered by some form of insurance against lost. If it looks like your shipment stalled in transit, was signed for but didn't arrive, or something else went wrong, please first contact the shipper and see what you can do about filing a claim. If your claim is honored and you receive the reimbursement for the value insured, get in touch about a using your claim to order a replacement.

Material defect? Some of our rewards will be shipped directly from the manufacturer. In the event that it arrives safely from the shipper, please get in touch and we'll see what we can do about getting you a replacement.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
The SARS-CoV-2 Collection: In Support of Victims of Domestic Violence
  As we are all painfully aware, SARS-CoV-2 infection leads to COVID-19.  While the resulting lock-downs and stay-at-home orders have saved countless lives, reports of domestic violence and abuse have seen a sharp increase. This collection is meant to raise awareness of the impacts of the pandemic as well as to support and provide hope to those who have been impacted by it.

updates.update_userinfo: Less than 24 hours to back the Honeypot Collection by GlitchTextiles
updates.update_content:
MALWARE TRANSFORMED INTO TEXTILES
I setup cloud servers to trick hackers into attacking them. The trick is called a honeypot and it traps malware uploaded onto them. The Honeypot Collection was created by translating the malware these servers have collected into woven textiles!

campaign.story:
BLACK: Remastered
In a world that already fears and hates them – what if only Black people had super powers?
After miraculously surviving being gunned down by police, a young man learns that he is part of the biggest lie in history. Now he must decide whether it's safer to keep it a secret or if the truth will set him free 
We launched BLACK on Kickstarter in February 2016, campaigning for funds to complete the project – backers helped us achieve that goal in four days. The outpouring of support for BLACK has been phenomenal and has opened up amazing opportunities. The campaign ended at nearly 300% above the funding goal. Since then, the project has grown: we were approached by Black Mask Studios to print BLACK as a periodical series, we’re working on subsequent stories, and BLACK was nominated for seven Glyph Awards – winning for best cover of 2017.
Even after our campaign ended, people still ask how they can contribute – so we were bringing BLACK back to give people the last chance to get the exclusive limited edition.
For this campaign, we’re seeking funds to have our amazing toner, Derwin Roberson remaster the entire book for all backers. 
Not only will this give the book a seamless look from start to finish, but also offer one last chance to get this limited-edition of the Kickstarter-exclusive collected edition of BLACK – plus a few extras.
We’re including new swag in rewards, and adding a special sneak peek into the next core book – backers will get a chance to see it first! Funds will go to re-tones, the teaser for book two, plus packing and shipping rewards.
There would be no BLACK if not for the support of our backers and we wanted to take this opportunity to allow anyone who missed the original campaign to get access to the limited edition of the book. It’s been a wild ride, and we hope you’ll join us as we continue our journey.
Stretch Goals
If we reach this goal, we’ll have BLACK professionally translated into French. This edition will be made available for digital distribution and to backers who prefer to read comics in French.
Should we reach this goal, BLACK will be professionally translated into Spanish. This edition will be made available for digital distribution and to backers who prefer to read comics in Spanish.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Risks and Challenges
Crowdfunding is such a huge factor for an independent comic. Backers give us the financial leverage to tell our story the way we want. Without you we’d be at the whim of entities that may want us to tell BLACK their way — your help is vital.
 
Our biggest challenge is time… we have a lot of people to thank and send rewards out to, but we’d be ecstatic to add your name to the list of supporters of BLACK.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: AND WE BACK, AND WE BACK
updates.update_content:
Whaddup, y’all!
We’ve just launched our Kickstarter for WHITE, the second part of the trilogy that started with our critically acclaimed graphic novel, BLACK.
It’s hard to believe that three years ago we took a chance that people might back the concept: “what if only black people had superpowers.” It was an idea partially borne out of not seeing black people in positions with agency and how that results in a lack of representation in comics.

We’ve received an update from our distribution partner that books are going out this week!
Sorry for the delay.
Printing and shipping all of the copies slammed our small operation, but we’re determined and glad that limited editions of BLACK are finally rolling out.

Thank you all so much for your support!
As always we could not do this without your support. We can't wait to get the remastered version of BLACK into your hands. You helped us reach our goal so fast it made our heads spin. 
Something that will make your heads spin is our good friend Felipe Smith's DEATH METAL ZOMBIE COP!

A message to our previous Kickstarter backers: 
We want to let you know that we appreciate all of your support and also your patience. 
This team has been working non-stop to bring you BLACK, VOL 1. Our goal remains to give you the best book possible, which has taken more time than we could have anticipated. One unanticipated hurdle was losing two toners during the course of the project. We’ve done our best to be transparent while focusing on getting chapters out to you regularly.

campaign.story:
UPDATE!! We're increasing our goal...
Full project details are still below, but we have some incredible news that impacts our fundraising. We can't yet fully share the specifics, BUT the basic gist is that we were just awarded a camera package grant by an amazing company and we'll be filming this on an outrageously beautiful camera. This is great news, but along with the nicer camera comes the need for additional accessories, insurance, and crew. We priced this out and we'll need to raise $1,700 more than we originally thought (we didn't want to ask for more than we needed) in order to accommodate, so we're implementing a stretch goal of $13,699 in these final hours. We've met our original goal thanks to our beautiful backers, so if you're just checking us out and see our published goal is almost met, please consider helping us with our stretch goal (Kickstarter doesn't allow projects to increase their published goal once the campaign has launched). Thank you!!!
Producer Gracie, Dog Riley, Director John, Cinematographer Adriana & Writer Youthana
Well, hello there!
We couldn't be more excited to make this movie, and we hope you'll join us in bringing it to life. Movies are expensive, even short ones, and this particular movie is going to cost about $15,000 (which is probably less than George Clooney spends on spa water in any given year). We've already raised some funds independently, but we still have a good ways to go. It's likely that your money is hard-earned, though maybe hard-borrowed (or easily handed down?), so we'll appreciate anything you can spare. That said, we have some really cool (and unique) rewards to offer for those who can contribute, including some limited bonus rewards from members of our talented crew. These include original drawings, tarot readings (not kidding), headshots, custom framing, and even illustrated portraits (of you!).
We're all volunteering our time (and roping our friends into doing the same) and calling in favors, but there are plenty of costs that are unavoidable. It's always good to understand how your contribution is helping, so here are some examples:
- $10 will buy a ceramic cat (the movie's hero prop... MEOW)
- $25 will purchase a student film permit for one day (a necessary evil)
- $50 will pay for a first aid kit (we're very safe, but boo-boos happen)
- $100 will cover drinking water (we're not cute when we're dehydrated)
- $250 will feed our cast & crew for one day (so many mouths to feed!)
- $500 will pay for Hannah's wardrobe & makeup (we need to transform a healthy actor into a cancer patient)
- $1000 will cover the location fees for Hannah & Elwood's house (please don't make us kick them to the curb)
- $2500 will cover the cost of production design (PJ's house is a doozy)
We've included lots of info about the project and our team below, in case you like to read and have nothing better to do.
xo,
The Elwood Takes a Lover Team
  SYNOPSIS: A dying, cantankerous woman wants to ensure her quasi-helpless-but-loveable husband has someone to care for him when she's gone. Suspecting he's a closeted homosexual, she tries (with a little help from her hospice nurse) to reunite him with the man she thinks was his first, unrequited love.
CHARACTERS:
- Hannah (60s, ornery, selfless, married to Elwood)
- Elwood (60s, quiet but loving, closeted, a bit clueless)
- PJ (60s, reclusive, ceramic cat aficionado, Elwood's first love)
- Dennis (30s, wears Crocs, loves people, Hannah's nurse)
GENRE: Drama/Comedy  
EXPECTED RUNNING TIME : Approx. 15 minutes
PRODUCTION DATES: July 27 – 31, 2017
FILMING LOCATION: Los Angeles, CA & surrounding areas
TONE: Drama when it needs to be. Comedy when it can’t help it. Think About Schmidt meets Steel Magnolias plus Baskets.
     John Palmer, Director (pull up a chair, this guy likes to ramble)
John Palmer is a director, writer, and producer whose work spans fiction, nonfiction, and experimental projects. As a first-generation college student, John earned his BFA in Fine Art at San Francisco Art Institute and is currently in his final year as an MFA candidate in Film and Television Production at USC’s School of Cinematic Arts.
John is a selected co-writer on the USC/James Franco/Elysium Bandini feature film adaptation of THE COUNT OF MONTE CRISTO, and is an intern at the Sundance Institute’s Documentary Film Program. He was recently invited to the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Artist Academy for emerging filmmakers at the 2016 New York Film Festival, and was a member of the VFX production team on Marvel’s DOCTOR STRANGE.
John received the LGBT Awareness Award at the 2016 Don Thompson LGBT Film Festival for his short film “Pitbull.” He was also honored with a faculty award nomination for his work as a producer on the USC-funded documentary “al imam,” about one of the world's only female Muslim religious leaders. The film recently inked a distribution deal with 7th Art Releasing.
John’s experimental 16mm and super-8 short films have screened at venues such as REDCAT and Pacific Film Archive. He has been selected for artist residencies at Echo Park Film Center and AICAD’s New York Studio Program, and awards including the James Broughton Film Award and a Princess Grace Foundation Film Honorarium. As a programmer, John has also presented screenings for American Cinematheque, Artists Television Access, and Echo Park Film Center.
At USC, John founded the Oscar Wao Cinema Club, in which students screened movies featuring underrepresented characters and discussed ways to improve inclusivity on both sides of the lens. He is also a founding programmer of the School of Cinematic Arts’ “Our Voices” Speakers Series, which hosts an inclusive roster of entertainment industry professionals from diverse backgrounds. Recent guests include Cheryl Boone Isaacs, Andrew Ahn, and John Singleton.
Outside of the film world, John has logged ten years as a volunteer at The Trevor Project, dedicated to suicide prevention and crisis intervention for LGBTQ youth.
Preview John's class work from USC: https://vimeo.com/173572403
  Gracie Corapi, Producer (you're off the hook, she knows how to keep it brief)
Gracie Corapi is a Tennessee-born dancer-turned-filmmaker, currently earning her M.F.A. at USC’s School of Cinematic Arts. Her focuses of study are writing, producing, and cinematography, spanning both documentary and fiction. She previously earned her B.A. in Dance and Media Arts from American University in Washington, D.C., where she filmed micro-documentaries for local dance artists and was a member of the contemporary dance company, Christopher K. Morgan & Artists.
  Youthana Yuos, Writer (more brevity... take a hint, John)
Youthana Yuos is a writer and director from Harrisburg, PA. He graduated from Penn State in 2007 with a degree in Information Sciences and Technology before earning his Masters in 2011 for Information Systems. Now having switched gears from IT to film, he is currently studying cinematic arts at the University of Southern California where he was recently awarded the Jack Nicholson Scholarship for Directing in 2016.
  Adriana Serrato, Cinematographer (seriously, why is John's bio longer than these three combined?!)
Adriana Serrato, born in San Francisco and raised in Geneva, Switzerland, returned to the United States to pursue a career in the arts. She attended the Corcoran College of Art and Design in Washington D.C., studying Visual Arts and discovering a passion for photography, which eventually led to her interest in filmmaking. She is currently pursuing her M.F.A at USC with a focus in cinematography.
  Nicholas Manting Brewer, Post Production Supervisor (funny but true: Nick was *not* forced to include the last two sentences here)
Nicholas Manting Brewer is an award winning editor with an interest in creating immersive and experimental films, animation, and VR content. He graduated from New College of Florida in 2012 with a BA in Cultural & Visual Anthropology. Nicholas believes in bridging public service with filmmaking. He is an AmeriCorps VISTA alumnus whose novel use of video and photographic advertising earned him the Florida Campus Compact VISTA Recognition Award. He is pursuing his MFA in Production from University of Southern California’s School of Cinematic Arts. Throughout his career, he hopes to explore diversity through interfacing with directors from around the world to share a broader spectrum of the human experience. In this Nicholas's humble opinion, John Palmer is a hero of Batman-level proportions, and he would follow him to the end of the earth. He's also incredibly excited to be a part of the talented team bringing Elwood Takes a Lover to the screen.
  (some thoughts from our director John on why this fun story with heart is worth telling, and how he plans to go about doing it)
I was mostly raised by my grandma, and like Hannah she was quite a cantankerous person, but under that was a heart of gold which wanted the people in her life to be taken care of. She passed away during my first year of graduate school, and even though my friend Youthana created the story and characters, I know this person well.
Elwood’s sort of a combination of my grandfather, who’s 88 and struggling to take care of himself in a small town after my grandma died, and another close family member who passed away many years ago. I always knew this person as straight, but I found suggestions after they died that they’d carried on a clandestine affair with a same-sex friend. I’ve always wondered what their life would have been like if they’d been able to live openly as I’m so lucky to do.
So I connected in a very real and personal way to Elwood and Hannah. Telling LGBT stories is also important to me as a filmmaker, and I love that this is a portrayal of queerness that doesn’t fall prey to stereotypes but instead thrives on nuance and complexity. There is a quiet hopefulness at play in Elwood’s affirmation, in PJ’s patience, and in Hannah’s journey being fulfilled in an unexpected way.
The film will be full of warm colors, and quiet, controlled images—taking a cue from filmmakers like Ozu and Conrad Hall—that mirror the lives of its characters. We’ll shoot largely on sticks and dollies, with plenty of wides and two shots to emphasize world and relationships, and we’ll move in close on longer lenses for the big emotional moments.
The simplicity of this story is a big reason I’m so excited to direct it. It will allow us to focus on craft, to build this world and these characters, and to take time to get it right. I think my strengths as a director are working with actors to craft honest performances and leading a team collaboratively. I’m excited to expand my skills in terms of directing the camera and blocking actors, and I’m looking forward to taking those things to the next level in my work and making cinematic magic with my collaborators.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Films are big, constantly evolving beasts. There are inherently a lot of risks involved. It might suck. It might get delayed. It might never even get made. But we're putting those chances at 3%, 5%, and 0.2%, respectively. We have an incredible team, focused on bringing this story to life, and we're working with a team of faculty advisors to ensure nothing flies too far off the rails. Also, our director is paying the university thousands of dollars for a thesis credit and he's most likely not gonna bail.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
To our infinitely radiant backers:
We know it's been a while since our last update, but we have some incredible news to share and we wanted you to hear it from us before we posted on social media...
After screening at over 15 festivals around the world this past year, Elwood Takes a Lover has been selected for the American Pavilion Emerging Filmmaker Showcase at the Cannes Film Festival! This is a really great honor since they only advance 20-30 films as finalists for the showcase.

Tomorrow marks a year to the day that we started production, and an update is long overdue. The latest news is included below, and we wanted to say thanks again to our backers for making all of this possible. You rock our world!
We received a very nice write-up in the San Francisco Bay Times, as the lead story in their Arts & Entertainment section. The print version is below, and here's the web link if you'd like to share:
http://sfbaytimes.com/elwood-takes-lover-brings-lgbt-seniors-big-screen/
We've also had a successful festival run so far, including lots of love from LGBT fests and the Oscar-qualifying HollyShorts Film Festival. Here's a list of all festivals to date:Mardi Gras Film Festival - Sydney, Australia
Don Thompson LGBT Film Festival - USC School of Cinematic Arts
OUTshine Film Festival - Miami, Florida
Tel Aviv International LGBT Film Festival - Tel Aviv, Israel
Out Film CT: Connecticut LGBT Film Festival - Hartford, Connecticut
Queers in Shorts - Cambridge, UK
GLITTER! Oklahoma LGBTQ Film Festival - McAlester, Oklahoma
HollyShorts Film Festival* - Los Angeles, California
North Carolina Gay & Lesbian Film Festival* - Durham, North Carolina
Out on Film: Atlanta LGBT Film Festival* - Atlanta, Georgia

updates.update_userinfo: Private preview link - FOR YOUR EYES ONLY!
updates.update_content:
Hello Backers of our Dreams,
Our movie is just about ready for the world! We're forever in your debt for helping us make this a reality. THANK YOU!
We have a lot of exciting news to share below. We hope those of you who will be in the Los Angeles area can join us for the screening.

Hello Best Backers Ever (yes, that's been verified),
We have some exciting news, and we wanted you to be the first to hear it. Drum roll, please...

Helloooooo,
We know we've been quiet lately, but that's not because we don't love you. We've been busy working on the movie and haven't had a lot to report. But we just passed our first post-production milestone... we're picture locked!! For those of you less familiar with the filmmaking process, that means that picture editing is now complete, and will no longer be fussed with, so that the other finishing elements (e.g. sound, music) can begin.

Hello patrons of our art,
It's late and we're coming off of five long days of filming (not to mention months of prep), so we'll keep this brief. We just officially wrapped production on our little movie. Our cast and crew were extraordinary, and we had so much fun it's almost embarrassing. Thank you again for helping us tell this story. We couldn't have done it without you, and you have our undying love and affection (and probably already did, tbh). THANK YOU!!!

campaign.story:
This Kickstarter Gold campaign is intended to raise funds to support the production and recording of an album of music for cats and their humans. In 2015, I created a Kickstarter campaign for the first-ever album of music that was composed just for cats. After the album was released there was a flood of heartwarming feedback from cat owners - and a number of requests for a second album. Although all of the songs on that first album contained music that was designed to make the song palatable for humans, one of the songs, Lolo’s Air, was designed to be music that could be shared by both the cats and their human companions. 
This second album will contain eight songs that will all be intended for feline-human sharing. It is a bit tricky to create, but I enjoy the extra effort because I love the idea that music can enhance the connections between cat and companion. This second album will consist entirely of the next generation of this shared music. Although I have been working on music for dogs and horses, the letters and reviews from the first album were so encouraging that I decided to make the creation of a second album my first priority. 
All of our digital downloads will be available in three formats, mp3 (compressed), 44kHz (CD quality), and 96kHz (highest quality). In the studio, we use special microphones and audio equipment that record very high frequencies. We do this because, when it comes to high hearing, dogs get the PR but cats can actually hear higher than dogs. All of the instruments that I use are acoustic-based to appeal to the high-resolution hearing of cats since natural sounds are much more complex and varied than electronic music.
  PLAY

The video above outlines how I came up with the idea and a thumbnail sketch of how it works. The scientific foundation of this music is strong and getting stronger. Please check out the attached journal articles and news reports (below) on music for cats for more information. The music for monkeys and music for cats that I created were both tested and shown to be effective in studies conducted by the University of Wisconsin-Madison.
I am eager to spread the word about animal sentience and their capacities for appreciating beauty - as long as it is designed for them - so please have a listen to a talk that I gave recently at the National Academy of Sciences "Beauty is in the Eye of the Species" by visiting the MIT Press site: http://arteca.mit.edu/video/david-e.-teie-beauty-eye-species
Read the study on music for monkeys...
Affective responses in tamarins elicited by species-specific music http://rsbl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/6/1/30.short
...and the study on music for cats.
Cats prefer species-appropriate music http://www.appliedanimalbehaviour.com/article/S0168-1591(15)00060-X/abstract http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.applanim.2015.02.012
Check out the news reports on music for cats in.... The New York Times:
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/01/style/cat-music-for-cats-david-teie.html?_r=1
CNN's Great Big Story:
https://www.greatbigstory.com/stories/cat-composer
BBC World News:
http://www.bbc.com/news/av/magazine-35529284/musician-composes-music-to-soothe-cats
The Today Show article:
http://www.today.com/pets/felines-react-david-teie-s-music-cats-album-t92026
and Time Magazine:
http://time.com/4538773/man-makes-music-for-cats/
This Kickstarter Gold campaign is to fund the production of a full album of music to share. We all know that love is the ultimate connecting force, and I have often thought that the best music is like love in sonic form. With this music I hope to bring a new enhancement to the connection between our two species. Cats and their humans sharing one music.
As it was for the first Kickstarter campaign and album, a portion of the proceeds will be donated to animal shelters and the music will be provided for free to shelters and hospitals that do not practice declawing.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As I mentioned, if everything is balanced just right, it is possible to blend music for humans and music for cats, to create a shared experience through music that I hope will be enjoyable to both you and your cat.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Twin Releases - Album and Study Results
updates.update_content:
Dear Backers,
This will be my last news-’n-thanks message to you, since we’re almost done here! The digital downloads have been delivered and the CDs, being manufactured now, will be sent out as soon as we have received them.
Another Study Confirms the Efficacy of Music for Cats

Dear Backers,
Just a quick update: seven of the eight songs are now recorded and mixed and ready to be blended with the special sauce. The musicians were all stellar and the environment and expertise of Nico at Sweet Spot studio were sweet-spot-on.
Onward!

updates.update_userinfo: All Eight Songs Are Now Composed And Being Recorded
updates.update_content:
Dear Backers,
I have been recording and mixing songs and will be rehearsing with the larger groups this week and expect to finish recording soon thereafter. Even though that still leaves mastering and production, at least the amount of music on the album will be fifty four minutes!

Dear Backers, 
I will make this update in two parts: one for those of you who have less time and a second part for those who have more time and a bit of interest in the process and the philosophy of music. 
Part One. 50 + minutes

Happy Valentine’s Day!
This Valentine post is for the love between you and your cat. That relationship is the well of inspiration that I draw from when I compose the music… so I guess this is something of a Thank-You-Card-Valentine.
I spend time before composing the music to reflect on the affection between cats and their humans. Doing so opens up the right musical arteries. Mind you, my attention to the relationship doesn’t really affect the bandwidth of the music that is intended for the cats. That music is created from a knowledge of their vocalizations and development - human sensibilities must be left out of it. Intuition does guide the human layer of the music, however, then the two are blended. More than once I have had a tear in my eye and a smile on my face as I compose this music - that’s the hoped-for combination! It may sound odd to read of my satisfaction with the progress of the album since it is now behind schedule, but I am genuinely pleased with it.

Dear Backers,
A hearty thanks to all who played the Erhu sample for their cats and wrote about the experience. I have removed the sample because I have enough info to move forward on this.
The outcome from more than 100 respondents:

Dear Backers, 
I was in the recording studio again last week and the music is beginning to take shape. More on that in the future, for now, there is a small request that I would ask of those of you who would like to set aside a couple of minutes in their schedules for experimentation.
Just a Little Background:

Dear Backers,
MusicforCats Album 2 is about to go to the recording studio!
My first task was to improve some of the cat-specific instruments.  I am now happy with the purr instruments (I have thirteen that have made the cut for use in the new album).  I needed some improved suckling instruments and I am now pleased with the new sounds.  Purrhaps most cat owners will not be able to tell the difference, but I hope and expect that the cats will.

Dear Backers,
I have been tackling the challenge of weaving human and cat music from a few different perspectives and I have found each to be rewarding, both from the outgoing expression of a composer and the incoming reception of a listener. The process of discovery is thrilling for me. Yes, I used the word "thrilling". Roller coasters, skydiving, finding new ways to weave melodies designed for very different species - they all meet up at the same club.

campaign.story:
Since 2016, I’ve been working on the "168:01" project- an endeavor supported by the global community to help the College of Fine Arts at the University of Baghdad restock the books that were destroyed in the 2003 invasion of Iraq. With the generous donations we received from our initial Kickstarter campaign, we have collected over 1600 books that are currently in the final process of being shipped to Baghdad. 
The students are thrilled to get these treasured books in their hands. However, the university is not equipped to receive the large amount of books, nor is there a suitable space where the students can read and study. 
We are reaching out for your support to help renovate the College of Fine Arts' library. Our volunteer architect Wei Cai has developed a practical yet affordable design from locally accessible building materials that will both house the books and provide a communal reading space for the students. 
Render by Wei Cai.
  Render by Wei Cai.
  Render by Wei Cai.
WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS WILL SUPPORT
Lumber 
Tables  
Chairs
Fixtures
Hardware
Paint
  Photo courtesy of the Esker Foundation. Photo by John Dean
In “168:01”, visitors encounter an austere library containing empty white books. The project positions viewers as potential participants whose contributions fund educational texts from a wish list compiled by students and faculty. As the installation accrues donations, volunteers replace the blank books with new texts during weekly performances, and the library’s shelves become saturated with knowledge and vibrancy. At the end of the exhibition, all donated texts are shipped to Baghdad. 
In 2016, we ran the first Kickstarter campaign to raise money for the first wave of art books and related shipping expenses. The books collected were initially used as part of the "168:01" museum installations at the Art Gallery of Windsor & The Esker Foundation, and are now scheduled to be shipped to the University of Baghdad.
Check out our first Kickstarter page here
More about the "168:01 exhibition at the Art Gallery of Windsor
More about the "168:01" exhibition at The Esker Foundation
“168:01” has the potential to replace all of the 70,000 books lost. After two exhibitions in Canada in 2016, world-wide press coverage, and the participation of hundreds of donors and volunteers, “168:01” is already making an impact on the students and faculty at the University of Baghdad by making a connection between Baghdad and the rest of the art world while putting a spotlight on Iraq’s artistic production.
"168:01" will continue in its efforts to replenish the library in the coming years. Beginning with an exhibition that opened at the Dunlop Art Gallery on May 5th, 2017, the project is now on a four-venue tour in the US and Canada through 2018. A unique version of the installation will also be on view as part of "The New Observatory" at FACT, Liverpool from June 22nd - October 1st, 2017.
More about the "168:01" exhibition at the Dunlop Art Gallery
More about "168:01" at FACT's "The New Observatory"
Iraq has a long history of cultural loss. Participating in this campaign, and in the "168:01" project in general, is just a small way to help transform destruction into a fresh start for Iraq's next generation of artists. 
PROJECT BACKGROUND
During the Islamic Golden Age in the 13th century, an invading Mongol army set fire to all the libraries of Baghdad, including the famed House of Wisdom, or Bayt al-Hikma. Legend describes the invaders throwing the Bayt al-Hikma’s entire library into the Tigris River to create a bridge of books for their army to cross. The pages bled ink into the river for seven days, at the end of which the books were drained of knowledge. 
Illustrations by Judith Shimer
“168:01” refers to the first moment when grief is transformed into a call to action, signaling the beginning of a struggle to move forward from the ashes of ruin.
  $10 Reward: Al-Mutanabbi Street Postcard
  $15 Reward: 168:01 Exhibition Catalog
  $25 Reward: Limited Edition Artist Book. Photo by Nadja Pelkey.
  $30 Reward: Limited Edition Artist Book + Postcard

  $100, $1K, $5K & $10K Rewards: "The Ashes Series: Dark Palace" & Extras!
  $500 Reward: "The Ashes Series" 8 x 10 Combo & Extras
  $2,500 Reward: "The Ashes Series" Mini Suite & Extras
  Wafaa Bilal is renowned for provoking dialogue about international politics and internal dynamics through high profile, technologically-driven art projects that employ the use of robotics, the Internet, and photographic mobile mapping. His work is informed by the experience of fleeing his homeland of Iraq and existing simultaneously in two worlds—his home in the “comfort zone” of the United States and his consciousness of the “conflict zone” in Iraq.
Bilal’s work is represented in major public collections, including Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, Qatar; Museum of Contemporary Photography, Chicago; Milwaukee Art Museum; and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, California. He has exhibited extensively in galleries and institutions throughout the world, including the US, Thailand, Iraq, the UK, Dubai, Lebanon, France, and Germany, and he has served on the panels of over twenty major global universities and institutions, including the Tate Modern, UK; Harvard University; Stanford University; Museum of Art and Design; the Global Art Forum, Qatar; and the Inter-Society for the Electronic Arts, Turkey. His work has been reviewed in major publications, including ARTnews, Art in America, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, and Newsweek, and he is the co-author of the critically-acclaimed 2008 publication "Shoot an Iraqi: Arts, Life and Resistance Under the Gun".
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The original Kickstarter campaign for "168:01" was truly an amazing experience. We were over 650% funded and the outpour of support we received was incredible. That having been said, we could have been better prepared to deal with all of the responsibilities that come along with running a popular campaign and mounting such a large-scale project. The "168:01" team was small in the beginning, so we have added a few new volunteer team members to ensure we are not stretching ourselves thin with the tasks we need to accomplish. It has been an excellent learning experience, and we are taking what we have learned to make adjustments to the way we will be running this new campaign:

1. Updates - Our new volunteer Outreach Coordinator, Christine Donley, will ensure the campaign page is updated more regularly with developments on the campaign, more detailed reports of what we have already accomplished between the beginning of "168:01" and now, and future developments with the project on whole. 

2. Rewards - Based on experience and backer feedback received during our last campaign, we have developed a new system that will guarantee a timelier delivery of all rewards. 

3. Challenges - In general, the implementation of "168:01"'s original goal went very well. We created the installation, successfully created our system of exchange with viewers, and collected over 1600 books to date for the College of Fine Arts. 

The main challenge we face is with getting the books delivered to the school and finding a place in the library to house them. Shipping to Iraq is not as simple as shipping to other countries and we will be working on the remodel remotely. We may face some delays, but we are fully confident that the books will be delivered and the library will be updated.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Update from Chicago
Over the summer, 168:01 was part of the first National Veterans Art Museum Triennial as Conflict Exchange (CX).  CX is a series of social platforms in the format of stores that explore the equity and relationships of post-conflict. In this inaugural edition, Wafaa presented veteran artists Alicia Dietz and Drew Cameron. Their work was featured as part of this social platform. CX was developed as an extension of 168:01.

We've got lots of great news (and photos) to share about the progress of the building of the Reading Room and the first shipment of books arriving in Baghdad.  
Happy New Year 168:01 Backers and Supporters!  
The 168:01 team in Baghdad, the US, and Canada have been busy behind the scenes bringing everything together to get the library and reading room ready for use by the students.  
What's happening?

We are disappointed to report that our Livestream Q&A scheduled for 6:00pm is cancelled. Wafaa has been traveling and was scheduled to be home by now, but his return has been delayed. We may reschedule for a future date, so keep your eyes peeled for the announcement! In the meanwhile, keep sending us your questions and suggestions for the Livestream. We want to hear from you!

Today we are sharing an interview with another 168:01 volunteer, Christine Donley. Christine has helped out with collecting book donations, running the Facebook page for 168:01, and managing the project updates on the current Kickstarter campaign.

Only one week left to pledge! Remember to tune in to our Livestream on Monday, July 17th at 6:00pm EST and have your questions ready! You can chat live with Wafaa, or submit them in advance:
Livestream Q&A with Wafaa Bilal
---
Calling all universities! "168:01" would like to take a tour.

We have 9 days left until the end of the campaign for 168:01: The Next Chapter and are almost halfway to our $10,000 Reach Goal! 
As you may have noticed, we were conservative with our initial campaign goal. $2,500 is a modest amount for such a large undertaking, but we wanted to make sure we would be fully funded and raise enough to at least get the ball rolling on the most important parts of the College of Fine Arts' library remodel.

campaign.story:
Hi! I'm Karyn Parsons. I played Hilary Banks on the TV show The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air. I am the founder of Sweet Blackberry, an award-winning organization whose mission is to bring little-known stories of African-American achievement to kids. 
Sweet Blackberry's mission is to share stories that empower and instill a sense of pride in children. Previous films by Sweet Blackberry have received the prestigious Parent’s Choice Award and Learning Magazine’s Teacher’s Choice Awards, among others. They were narrated by noted actors Chris Rock, Alfre Woodard and Queen Latifah. All films are currently available to stream on Netflix and have been distributed to libraries and schools all over the world and have made a difference!
 Sweet Blackberry is currently developing its fourth animated short sharing the inspiring story of Bessie Coleman, the first African-American female pilot. 
Bessie grew up during a time where aviation schools in the United States would not let her learn to fly because she was a woman and she was Black. Without letting this prevent her from accomplishing her dream, Bessie taught herself, French, moved to France and earned her license from the renowned Caudron Brothers School of Aviation. 
Bessie Coleman's story shows children that despite what odds may be stacked against them, they can be anything. Bessie broke a glass ceiling in the United States that limited individuals wanting to be a pilot to one race and gender. It is our duty at Sweet Blackberry to share her story with the world.
Bessie's story belongs to all of us. We need collaborators to create a 20-minute, animated film bringing Bessie's inspiring story to screens everywhere. Together, we will make a 20-minute, animated film, to be narrated by award-winning actor Laurence Fishburne.  This inspiring story will be distributed to libraries and schools, broadcast to a wide audience, and enjoyed in homes across the country. 
Celebrated children's book illustrator R. Gregory Christie (who has worked with the New Yorker and New York Times, as well as in over 50 books) has signed on to create the look of the film (including the great illustrations above).
In addition, there are the important touches: title design; sound, mixing and music clearances; an actor, extras, equipment and all the other things needed to shoot a live action sequence; post production and an editor; as well as digital mastery so the project is ready to land in a classroom, on TV or in a home.
Sweet Blackberry is a 501c3, non-profit organization, and all donations are tax deductible. We hope you, too, will become a part of the Sweet Blackberry family, and help get these stories out!
Thanks so much for taking the time, and thanks in advance for your support.            
Spend the afternoon with Hilary and Ashley Banks! Pledge items include the opportunity to spend an afternoon shopping and having lunch with Karyn and Tatyana! 
http://www.sweetblackberry.org
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The only real risk is NOT making our goal. In that event, we will be unable to produce this important story and get it in schools, libraries, and homes across the country. We really need to harness all the enthusiasm and support for Sweet Blackberry and its mission that we’ve received over the years, and channel it into funding to make this film!

There really are no foreseeable risks once we have attained funding, except perhaps, our narrator’s schedule changing on us, but as we are not a studio with loads of other productions lined up, we have a lot of flexibility.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Sweet Blackberry - Now on Patreon -- Rewards, Behind-the-Scenes Action & More!
updates.update_content:
Hi Everyone,
Thanks again for all of your support with our Kickstarter projects. We're so lucky to have such a supportive community behind us. Today, we launched a cool project that allows those of you interested to continue to witness the behind-the-scenes action of Sweet Blackberry through a platform called Patreon.
By joining Patreon, you will have the opportunity to receive additional Sweet Blackberry merchandise, listen in on monthly discussions on important issues surrounding Black history and so much more.

Hey, Everyone!
Most of you have already received your rewards from our Bessie campaign, but for those of you who haven't, don't worry, we're working on getting those to you!  Early next week, we will be sharing the Bessie Coleman digital download to those of you that supported our campaign for that award. We are in the process of having the DVDs created and will be packaging DVDs and the related Bessie items later this summer.  We are also working on getting the remaining celebrity items out and scheduled. As always, if you have any questions, don't hesitate to contact us as admin@sweetblackberry.org.

updates.update_userinfo: Flying Free: The Bessie Coleman Story at the Museum of the Moving Image

updates.update_content: Woohoo! It's done!
A couple weeks ago, I had the pleasure of interviewing Gigi Coleman Brooms, grand niece of Bessie Coleman, for Flying Free: The Bessie Coleman Story!

updates.update_userinfo: Kimberly, Chauncey, and Laurence, oh my!... Good stuff in the can!
updates.update_content:
Hi, Everyone!
I have some great updates for you on how our project is coming along! We had a great trip to L.A. last week and can't wait for you to see the finished project! 
I had the opportunity to interview pilot Kimberly Anyadike for the live action segment of Flying Free: The Bessie Coleman Story. At the age of 15, Kimberly became the youngest African American female to complete a transcontinental flight across the United States.

Hi Everyone, 
Thank you so much for your continued support. We're currently working to pull together the finishing touches to our Bessie Coleman project which is now expected to be released in May 2018! While we wait for the finished product, here's a sneak peek of a scene our animator Katherine Bianca Clark and illustrator R. Gregory Christie recently completed.
